concept_art_1.alt: An early rendering of Cinderella City's central court.
concept_art_1.caption: An early rendering of Cinderella City's central court.

aerial_60s_70s_1.alt: Cinderella City's unique layout as seen from the air on opening day in 1968.
aerial_60s_70s_1.caption: Cinderella City's unique layout as seen from the air on opening day in 1968.

blue_mall_60s70s_1.alt: The mall centered around a block-wide court called Blue Mall, which featured a stunning 35-foot fountain.
blue_mall_60s70s_1.caption: The mall centered around a block-wide court called Blue Mall, which featured a stunning 35-foot fountain.

blue_mall_60s70s_2.alt: The mall centered around a block-wide court called Blue Mall, which featured a stunning 35-foot fountain.
blue_mall_60s70s_2.caption: The mall centered around a block-wide court called Blue Mall, which featured a stunning 35-foot fountain.

blue_mall_60s70s_event_1.alt: A concert takes place in the Blue Mall.
blue_mall_60s70s_event_1.caption: A concert takes place in the Blue Mall.

blue_mall_60s70s_parking_1.alt: Cinderella City's scale required the use of parking decks and ramps to fit within its constraints.
blue_mall_60s70s_parking_1.caption: Cinderella City's scale required the use of parking decks and ramps to fit within its constraints.

blue_mall_60s70s_parking_2.alt: The giant complex was surrounded by 7,000 parking spaces on two levels.
blue_mall_60s70s_parking_2.caption: The giant complex was surrounded by 7,000 parking spaces on two levels.

blue_mall_80s90s_exterior_1.alt: The southeast Blue Mall entrance after the mall closed in 1997.
blue_mall_80s90s_exterior_1.caption: The southeast Blue Mall entrance after the mall closed in 1997.

cinder_alley_1.alt: Cinderella City featured a lower-level market and bazaar known as Cinder Alley, a precursor today's mixed-use retail.
cinder_alley_1.caption: Cinderella City featured a lower-level market and bazaar known as Cinder Alley, a precursor today's mixed-use retail.

plan_60s70s_1.alt: Cinderella City featured 5 sub-malls: Blue, Rose, Gold, Shamrock, and Cinder Alley.
plan_60s70s_1.caption: Cinderella City featured 5 sub-malls: Blue, Rose, Gold, Shamrock, and Cinder Alley.

parking_blue_mall_1.alt: Cinderella City was surrounded by a sprawling parking garage, seen here with a ramp leading below Blue Mall.
parking_blue_mall_1.caption: Cinderella City was surrounded by a sprawling parking garage, seen here with a ramp leading below Blue Mall.

rose_mall_60s70s_1.alt: Rose Mall as it appeared before opening in 1968.
rose_mall_60s70s_1.caption: Rose Mall as it appeared before opening in 1968.

rose_mall_60s70s_2.alt: The mezzanine level featured offices for lease, seen here from Rose Mall.
rose_mall_60s70s_2.caption: The mezzanine level featured offices for lease, seen here from Rose Mall.

rose_mall_80s90s_1.alt: Rose Mall as seen post-renovation in the mid-1980s.
rose_mall_80s90s_1.caption: Rose Mall as seen post-renovation in the mid-1980s.

ecc_abandoned_1.caption: Abandoned by Foley's in 1994, the empty department store is seen here attached to an ailing Cinderella City in 1996.

ecc_existing_north.caption: The Englewood Civic Center's north side formerly connected to Cinderella City Mall and now faces into a public plaza surrounded by mixed-use buildings.

ecc_existing_south.caption: The south side of the Englewood Civic Center is fronted by a parking deck much like the parking deck that once surrounded the entire mall.

ecc_post_demo_1.caption: The former Broadway Southwest department store as seen after Cinderella City was demolished in 1998. The right side of the building was once attached to the mall.

ecc_reuse_opt_5_terraces.caption: One option for reuse is installing a food hall in the lower level and peeling back the parking garage to reveal terraces down to the ground level, with replacement parking in a multifamily building offscreen.

villa_italia_grand_opening_1.caption: Villa Italia during its grand opening in March of 1966.

_1962_11_06_council_meeting.caption: A contentiousm 6-hour City Council meeting where citizens and business expressed opposition to a shopping center on the east Hampden site.

_1968_03_07_Von_Frellicks_start_fountain.caption:
The Von Frellick family pulls a lever to start the 35-foot fountain in the Blue Room on opening day. 

From left to right: Gerri Lu Von Frellick, Reba Mae Von Frellick, Gerri Von Frellick
_1968_03_07_Von_Frellicks_start_fountain.alt:
The Von Frellick family pulls a lever to start the 35-foot fountain in the Blue Room on opening day. 

From left to right: Gerri Lu Von Frellick, Reba Mae Von Frellick, Gerri Von Frellick

_1966_03_31_groundbreaking.caption:
Groundbreaking for Cinderella City. 

From right to left: Frank Johns, Denver Dry Goods Co.; Myron Neusteter, president of Neusteters; Larry Laman, J.C. Penney Co.; and Gerri Von Frellick
_1966_03_31_groundbreaking.alt:
Groundbreaking for Cinderella City. 

From right to left: Frank Johns, Denver Dry Goods Co.; Myron Neusteter, president of Neusteters; Larry Laman, J.C. Penney Co.; and Gerri Von Frellick

_1961_06_19_protestors.caption:
William Urban and Mrs. Kass Nachazel display some of the 97 posters painted by youngsters at a picnic rally of the Northeast Englewood Citizens Committee to drum up support for the committee's fight against the proposed Cinderella City shopping center. 
Englewood City Council will meet at 8pm Monday at the Englewood High School Field House to decide on rezoning for the area of the proposed center - the KLZ Radio Towers site on East Hampden Ave., just west of S. University Blvd.
_1961_06_19_protestors.alt:
William Urban and Mrs. Kass Nachazel display some of the 97 posters painted by youngsters at a picnic rally of the Northeast Englewood Citizens Committee to drum up support for the committee's fight against the proposed Cinderella City shopping center. 
Englewood City Council will meet at 8pm Monday at the Englewood High School Field House to decide on rezoning for the area of the proposed center - the KLZ Radio Towers site on East Hampden Ave., just west of S. University Blvd.

_1998_08_18_demolition_celebration__1_.caption: Englewood Mayor Tom Burns addresses the crowd before demolition beings in August 1998.
_1998_08_18_demolition_celebration__1_.alt: Englewood Mayor Tom Burns addresses the crowd before demolition beings in August 1998.

_1968_09_19_Joslins_opening.caption:
Mayor Elmer E. Schwab, left, of Englewood wields the shears at traditional ribbon-cutting ceremonies held Thursday as the new 100,000-square-foot Joslins Department store opened in Cinderella City. 

Watching are, from left: Gerri Von Frellick, developer of the 1.5 million-square-foot complex, Donald R. Chabot, Joslins president, and Andrew W. Bida, general manager of new store located on Gold Mall.
_1968_09_19_Joslins_opening.alt:
Mayor Elmer E. Schwab, left, of Englewood wields the shears at traditional ribbon-cutting ceremonies held Thursday as the new 100,000-square-foot Joslins Department store opened in Cinderella City. 

Watching are, from left: Gerri Von Frellick, developer of the 1.5 million-square-foot complex, Donald R. Chabot, Joslins president, and Andrew W. Bida, general manager of new store located on Gold Mall.
